## GAD-7 vs MAAS

GAD-7 vs MAAS Psychologists and social research scientists often find themselves needing to compare different questionnaires in their studies and research. A common comparison often made is that of the Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7) and the Maternal Antenatal Attachment Scale (MAAS), hence GAD-7 vs MAAS. Both these assessment instruments serve crucial roles in their respective fields, and understanding the correlation and divergences between them can yield significant insights.



## Compare the items in GAD-7 English and MAAS

* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import GAD-7 and MAAS into Harmony and harmonise them</a> - find similarities between the two instruments using our AI platform
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just GAD-7 into Harmony</a> - compare GAD-7 English with other instruments
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just MAAS into Harmony</a> - compare MAAS with other instruments


## Using Harmony for Comparisons

Working on GAD-7 vs MAAS can be a painstaking task considering the subjective measures and time needed. This is where the Harmony software proves to be invaluable. Harmony uses advanced AI models specifically designed for natural language processing to facilitate the process of harmonisation between different items in these questionnaires. It saves psychologists immense time and effort by enabling seamless comparison between both instruments, and even provides a percentage match for each question item in GAD-7 and MAAS.


## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
